author: gland2015
body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

write a c# program and regiser as windows service, and use powershell module execute "Get-PhysicalDisk" command

### Expected behavior

```console
1
```


### Actual behavior

```console
it is not return any
```


### Error details

```console
1
```


### Environment data

```powershell
1
```


### Visuals

1

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: The cmdlet works well in standalone PowerShell 7.2 Preview. So it's more of a local problem.

comments.author: gland2015
comments.body:
yes, it works well in my standalone PowerShell.
but in windows services program  has any difference? 
c# call powershell: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/scripting/developer/hosting/adding-and-invoking-commands?view=powershell-7.1

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: Has the service account  WMI permissions to do the operation?

comments.author: gland2015
comments.body:
it is SYSTEM account, use Adminstrators account is same. I add SYSTEM to wmi -> ROOT ( wmimgmt.msc) is same. 
Get-Disk / Mount-Disk / Get-Volume is work at windows service.

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body:
You might be a better error message with more details if you try getting it from CIM directly

```powershell
Get-CimInstance -ClassName MSFT_PhysicalDisk -Namespace Root/Microsoft/Windows/Storage
```

The `Storage` module is a CDXML one and essentially just calls this with some extra formatting on top.

comments.author: gland2015
comments.body: @jborean93  yes, This returns disk information, so Get-PhysicalDisk has bug.

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body: Weird, what's the full output you get back when trying to run `Get-PhysicalDisk`? If it's an error can you also run `$Error[0] | Select *` afterwards and share that output?

comments.author: gland2015
comments.body: @jborean93  Get-PhysicalDisk return nothing, not a error

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body: How is your service running the command, is it creating a new process calling `pwsh -Command Get-PhysicalDisk` or is it using the `System.Management.Automation` API to spin up a new pipeline?

comments.author: gland2015
jborean93
comments.body: Did you check with `ps.Streams.Error` to see if there are any errors in there. Because you are using the API you won't get errors through the `Invoke()` output as that's reserved for actual output of the cmdlet. I would also just simplify things by just invoking `ps.AddScript("Get-PhysicalDisk")` to rule out any other problems.

comments.author: gland2015
gland2015
comments.body: your windows service is ok? There are many error here. @jborean93

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body: Those don't look like errors but actual output indicating things work.

comments.author: gland2015
comments.body: so why it return nothing? when it is a ordinary program, it is work. when it is windows service, it not work. @jborean93

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body: I dont know, you shared a json as a comment and I assumed it just started working. What’s the context behind that message, did you check the error streams, did you try just calling the cmdlets withiut any of the extra calls you add on top.

comments.author: gland2015
comments.body: just the import-module and the command, you can try it as windows service?

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: Based on jborean93's thoughts I guess a root of the issue could be in the fact that Windows service has not a console.

comments.author: gland2015
comments.body: but Get-Disk / Mount-Disk / Get-Volume is return disk info at windows service. @iSazonov

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body:
Using psexec to replicate running the command as a service process (it runs from the PSExec service as SYSTEM) I cannot replicate your problem:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8462645/137258611-a4d23e59-2edf-4ffe-bff3-f16a8e2c4b09.png)

You need to look at the error stream of the pipeline after execution to see if there are any errors present that could help you identify what may be going wrong. Why it's running normally but not as a Windows service is what those errors should hopefully tell you.

comments.author: gland2015
comments.body: I have another question, I has execute "Import-Module Storage", when exxcute "Get-Disk", The first execution takes twice as long as the second.

comments.author: gland2015
comments.body: you should write a c# service, using System.Management.Automation API. @jborean93

comments.author: gland2015
comments.body:
like this https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/extensions/workers
Worker Services in .NET
Learn how to implement a custom IHostedService and use existing implementations with .NET.

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body: In the end I'm trying to give you hints of things to try, I'm not going out of my way to compile a service and run things. Once again try checking the error stream to find out if there are errors in there to give you a hint as to what is wrong. There's nothing else I can suggest without having that information.

comments.author: gland2015
comments.body: ok, thanks

comments.author: gland2015
comments.body: actually, Get-Disk replace Get-PhysicalDisk, so I want to know after execute "Import-Module Storage",  when execute "Get-Disk" twice,  The first execution takes twice as long as the second. @jborean93

comments.author: lostmsu

title: Get-PhysicalDisk cannot get disk when it run at a windows services
